citation.article-title: Alcanivorax borkumensis gen. nov., sp. nov., a new, hydrocarbon-degrading and surfactant-producing marine bacterium.

p.s: Description of Alcanivorax borkumensis sp. nov.
Alcanivorax borkumensis (bor.kum.en.sis. M.L. adj. borkumensis from the island of Borkum, a small island in Western-Elms harbour in the North Sea, located close to the German-Dutch border)
The cultures grow at 4-35¬∞C with an optimum between 25 and 30¬∞C.
Growth occurs at NaCl concentrations of 1.0-12.5% with an optimum between 3 and 10% NaCl.
Strains exhibit tweenase activity while agarase, amylase, arginine dihydrolase, ornithine decarboxylase, lysine decarboxylase, gelatinase and esculinase activities are not detected.
Growth is poor on complex bacteriological media and media containing carbohydrates and amino acids.

Aliphatic hydrocarbons, as well as selected short-chain fatty acids, including formate, acetate, propionate, methylpyruvate and Œ±-ketoglutarate, are used as sole or principal carbon source for growth.
Strains are able to grow on Œ±-, Œ≤- and ùõæ-hydroxybutyrates, although their polymers are not accumulated.

A mixture of active biosurfactants, glucose lipids, are produced, one of which consists of four 3-hydroxydecanoic acids linked together by ester bonds and coupled glycosidically with the C-1 of glucose.
The principal fatty acids in PLFA profile are 16:0, 16:1 and 18:1.
The G+C content of the DNA is 53.4 mol%.

According to the 16s rRNA sequence, the bacteria belong to the ùõæ-subclass of the Proteobacteria and occupy an intermediate position in a distinct, monophyletic cluster between the genera Marinobacter and Halomonas.
The type strain SK2T has been deposited in the German Collection of Microorganisms and Cell Cultures (DSMZ) as strain DSM 11573T.
